CALORIES_BURNED_CALCULATOR.TITLE: Calories Burned Calculator
CALORIES_BURNED_CALCULATOR.DESCRIPTION: Calculate calories burned while running with our free, accurate calculator. Enter your distance, time, and weight to estimate energy expenditure. Perfect for runners tracking fitness goals, weight loss, and training intensity.
CALORIES_BURNED_CALCULATOR.SUMMARY_SUB: Based on your distance, time and weight.

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: How accurate is the calories burned calculation?
FAQ.A1: Our calculator provides estimates based on established metabolic equations that consider your weight, distance, and time. Accuracy is typically within 10-15% for most runners. Individual factors like fitness level, running efficiency, and metabolism can affect actual calorie burn.
FAQ.Q2: What factors affect how many calories I burn while running?
FAQ.A2: Several factors influence calorie burn: body weight (heavier runners burn more), running speed and intensity, terrain (hills increase burn), weather conditions (heat/cold require more energy), and individual metabolism. Your body composition also plays a role in metabolic efficiency.
FAQ.Q3: Do I burn more calories running faster or running longer?
FAQ.A3: Both speed and duration increase calorie burn, but in different ways. Running faster burns more calories per minute, while running longer burns more total calories. For weight loss, total calorie burn matters most. Use our pace calculator to find sustainable speeds for longer runs.
FAQ.Q4: How does my weight affect calorie burn during running?
FAQ.A4: Heavier runners burn more calories because it takes more energy to move a larger mass. Generally, you burn about 0.63 calories per pound of body weight per mile (or 1.4 calories per kg per km). This is why weight is the most important factor in our calculation.
FAQ.Q5: Should I eat back the calories I burn while running?
FAQ.A5: It depends on your goals. For weight loss, create a moderate calorie deficit by not eating back all burned calories. For performance and recovery, especially during intense training, you may need to replace most calories burned. Monitor your energy levels and consider your training intensity when planning nutrition.
FAQ.Q6: How do I use this information for weight management?
FAQ.A6: To lose 1 pound of fat, you need to create a deficit of about 3,500 calories through diet and exercise combined. Track your daily calorie burn from running and combine with your BMR (basal metabolic rate) to understand your total daily energy expenditure. Aim for a sustainable deficit of 300-500 calories per day for healthy weight loss.

VO2MAX_CALCULATOR.TITLE: VO₂max Calculator
VO2MAX_CALCULATOR.DESCRIPTION: Calculate your VO₂ max from race performance. Used by athletes worldwide to estimate aerobic fitness and optimize training. Enter your recent race distance and finish time to get your VO₂ max estimation based on the proven Jack Daniels formula.

HOW_TO_USE.TITLE: How to Use the VO₂ Max Calculator
HOW_TO_USE.STEP1: 1. Choose your race distance: Select a recent race distance from 5K to marathon. For best accuracy, use a race you completed within the last 3-6 months at maximum effort.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP2: 2. Enter your finish time: Input your actual race finish time in hours, minutes, and seconds. Be as precise as possible for the most accurate VO₂ max estimation.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP3: 3. Get your result: Your estimated VO₂ max will be calculated using the Jack Daniels formula, widely used by running coaches and sports scientists worldwide.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP4: 4. Interpret your score: Compare your result with the ranges below and use it to set training goals and track fitness improvements over time.

FACTORS.TITLE: Factors Affecting VO₂ Max
FACTORS.AGE: Age: Typically decreases 1% per year after age 25

TRAINING_TIPS.TITLE: How to Improve Your VO₂ Max
TRAINING_TIPS.INTRO: Boost your aerobic fitness with these evidence-based training strategies:
TRAINING_TIPS.TIP1: High-Intensity Intervals: 3-8 minute intervals at 3K-5K race pace, 1-2 times per week
TRAINING_TIPS.TIP2: Tempo Runs: 20-40 minute runs at comfortably hard pace (15K-half marathon pace)
TRAINING_TIPS.TIP3: Long Runs: Build aerobic base with weekly long runs at conversational pace
TRAINING_TIPS.TIP4: Consistency: Train regularly for 6-12 weeks to see significant improvements

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: What is VO₂ Max and why is it important?
FAQ.A1: VO₂ Max is the maximum amount of oxygen your body can use during intense exercise, measured in milliliters per kilogram of body weight per minute. It's considered the gold standard for measuring aerobic fitness and endurance capacity. Higher VO₂ Max values indicate better cardiovascular fitness and running performance potential.
FAQ.Q2: How accurate is this VO₂ Max estimation?
FAQ.A2: This calculator uses the Jack Daniels formula, which is widely used by coaches and athletes. It provides a reasonable estimate based on recent race performance, typically accurate within 5-10% for trained runners. For the most precise measurement, consider laboratory testing with specialized equipment. Use our Finish Time Predictor to see how your VO₂ Max translates to race performance.
FAQ.Q3: What race distance should I use for the most accurate result?
FAQ.A3: Use a recent race time (within 3-6 months) from a distance you ran at maximum effort. Times from 5K to half marathon typically provide the most accurate estimates. Avoid using times from races where you didn't give full effort, ran in extreme weather, or on challenging terrain. Calculate your optimal training paces based on your estimated VO₂ Max.
FAQ.Q4: What are typical VO₂ Max values for runners?
FAQ.A4: Average recreational runners: 35-45 ml/kg/min. Competitive club runners: 45-55 ml/kg/min. Elite distance runners: 60-80+ ml/kg/min. Values vary by age, gender, and training background. Remember that VO₂ Max is just one factor in running performance - efficiency, lactate threshold, and mental toughness also matter significantly.
FAQ.Q5: How can I improve my VO₂ Max?
FAQ.A5: Improve VO₂ Max through high-intensity interval training, tempo runs, and consistent aerobic base building. Include 1-2 VO₂ Max workouts per week (3-8 minute intervals at 3K-5K race pace). Maintain a strong aerobic base with easy runs. Track your progress by monitoring your training intensity and retesting every 6-8 weeks.
FAQ.Q6: Does body weight affect VO₂ Max calculations?
FAQ.A6: Yes, VO₂ Max is expressed per kilogram of body weight, so changes in weight can affect your values. Losing excess weight typically improves VO₂ Max and running performance. However, extreme weight loss can reduce muscle mass and hurt performance. Use our BMI Calculator to find your optimal racing weight and body composition.

FINISH_TIME_PREDICTOR.TITLE: Race Time Predictor
FINISH_TIME_PREDICTOR.DESCRIPTION: Predict your race finish times for 5K, 10K, half marathon, and marathon distances. Based on proven formulas used by elite coaches. Enter your recent race time to get accurate predictions for goal setting and race planning.

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: How accurate are race time predictions?
FAQ.A1: Race time predictions are estimates based on your current fitness level and proven mathematical formulas. They're typically accurate within 2-5% for well-trained runners on similar terrain and weather conditions. Your actual performance may vary based on training, fitness level, race day conditions, and pacing strategy.
FAQ.Q2: What's the best race distance to use for predictions?
FAQ.A2: Recent race times from 5K to half marathon distances provide the most accurate predictions. A 10K time is often considered the gold standard for predicting longer distances. Use your most recent race result (within 6 months) for best accuracy. Calculate your target race pace based on these predictions.
FAQ.Q3: Why do my predicted times seem too fast or slow?
FAQ.A3: Predictions assume consistent training and similar race conditions. If predictions seem fast, you may need more endurance training for longer distances. If they seem slow, you might be undertrained for shorter, speed-focused races. Consider your current training volume and energy expenditure when evaluating predictions.
FAQ.Q4: How should I train based on these predictions?
FAQ.A4: Use predicted times to set realistic race goals and determine training paces. For marathon training, aim for long runs at 30-90 seconds per mile slower than predicted marathon pace. For 5K/10K training, include intervals at or slightly faster than predicted pace. Monitor your progress with regular time trials.
FAQ.Q5: Do these predictions work for all runners?
FAQ.A5: Predictions work best for trained runners with consistent racing experience. They may be less accurate for beginners, runners returning from injury, or those with significant strength/speed imbalances. Elite runners and recreational runners may see different accuracy levels due to training specificity and aerobic capacity differences.

PACE_CALCULATOR.TITLE: Running Pace Calculator
PACE_CALCULATOR.DESCRIPTION: Calculate running pace, time, and distance for marathon training, 5K preparation, and race planning. Enter any two values to calculate the third.

HOW_TO_USE.TITLE: How to Use the Pace Calculator
HOW_TO_USE.STEP1: 1. Enter any two values: Input distance, time, or pace - the calculator will automatically compute the missing value. Perfect for planning workouts or analyzing race performance.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP2: 2. Choose your units: Select between metric (kilometers, min/km) or imperial (miles, min/mile) units based on your preference or training program requirements.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP3: 3. Get instant results: See your calculated pace, time, or distance immediately. Use these values for training planning, race goal setting, or workout analysis.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP4: 4. Apply to training: Use the calculated pace for different training types - easy runs, tempo workouts, intervals, or race pacing strategies.

EASY_RUNS.TITLE: Easy/Recovery Runs
EASY_RUNS.DESC: Conversational pace - you should be able to speak in full sentences
EASY_RUNS.PACE: Pace: Significantly slower than 5K race pace (about 20-30% slower)
EASY_RUNS.PURPOSE: Purpose: Build aerobic base, promote recovery, increase weekly mileage safely

TEMPO_RUNS.TITLE: Tempo/Threshold Runs
TEMPO_RUNS.DESC: Comfortably hard pace - sustainable but challenging effort
TEMPO_RUNS.PACE: Pace: Slightly slower than 10K race pace (about 5-10% slower)
TEMPO_RUNS.PURPOSE: Purpose: Improve lactate threshold, race-specific fitness, mental toughness

INTERVALS.TITLE: Interval Training
INTERVALS.DESC: Hard effort - 5K race pace or faster for short repeats
INTERVALS.PACE: Pace: 3K-5K race pace for VO₂ max intervals
INTERVALS.PURPOSE: Purpose: Improve VO₂ max, running economy, speed, anaerobic capacity

LONG_RUNS.TITLE: Long Runs
LONG_RUNS.DESC: Steady, sustainable pace - focus on time/distance, not speed
LONG_RUNS.PACE: Pace: Moderately slower than marathon pace (about 10-20% slower)
LONG_RUNS.PURPOSE: Purpose: Build endurance, mental toughness, fat-burning efficiency

RACE_STRATEGY.TITLE: Race Pacing Strategies
RACE_STRATEGY.INTRO: Smart pacing is crucial for race success. Here are proven strategies for different race distances:

SHORT_RACES.TITLE: 5K & 10K Races
SHORT_RACES.STRATEGY1: 5K: Start slightly conservative, build through middle, strong finish
SHORT_RACES.STRATEGY2: 10K: Even pacing throughout, slight negative split if possible

LONG_RACES.TITLE: Half Marathon & Marathon
LONG_RACES.STRATEGY1: Half Marathon: Conservative first 5K, steady middle, strong final 5K
LONG_RACES.STRATEGY2: Marathon: Even pacing is critical, save energy for final 10K push

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: What is a good running pace for beginners?
FAQ.A1: For beginners, a good running pace is one where you can maintain a conversation while running. This typically ranges from 9-12 minutes per mile (5:30-7:30 per km). Focus on consistency and gradually building endurance rather than speed initially.
FAQ.Q2: How do I calculate my target marathon pace?
FAQ.A2: Your marathon pace should be 30-60 seconds per mile slower than your 10K pace, or about 15-30 seconds per km slower. Use recent race times with our Finish Time Predictor to estimate your marathon pace, and practice running at this pace during long training runs.
FAQ.Q3: What's the difference between pace and speed?
FAQ.A3: Pace is time per distance (e.g., 6:00 per mile), while speed is distance per time (e.g., 10 mph). Runners typically use pace because it's easier to maintain a consistent effort level and plan race strategies.
FAQ.Q4: How should I pace different race distances?
FAQ.A4: 5K: Start slightly slower than goal pace, build in middle, finish strong. 10K: Even pacing throughout. Half Marathon: Start conservatively, negative split if possible. Marathon: Even pacing is crucial, save energy for final 10K.
FAQ.Q5: What factors affect my running pace?
FAQ.A5: Weather (heat/humidity slow you down), terrain (hills and trails are slower), altitude (higher elevation reduces pace), fatigue level, hydration, and nutrition all significantly impact your running pace. Track your calories burned to optimize your nutrition strategy.

DISTANCE_UNIT_CONVERTER.TITLE: Distance Converter - Miles to Kilometers Calculator
DISTANCE_UNIT_CONVERTER.DESCRIPTION: Convert running distances between miles and kilometers instantly. Essential tool for international race planning, training programs, and GPS watch setup. Accurate conversion for 5K, 10K, half marathon, marathon, and custom distances.
DISTANCE_UNIT_CONVERTER.RESULT_SUBTITLE: Equivalent distances in kilometers and miles

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: What's the exact conversion between kilometers and miles?
FAQ.A1: 1 kilometer equals 0.621371 miles, and 1 mile equals 1.609344 kilometers. This tool uses precise conversion factors to ensure accuracy for all your training and racing needs. Understanding both units helps when following international training plans or racing abroad.
FAQ.Q2: Why do some countries use kilometers while others use miles?
FAQ.A2: Most countries worldwide use the metric system (kilometers), while the United States, United Kingdom, and a few others primarily use the imperial system (miles) for road distances. In running, this means race distances like 5K, 10K, and marathons are often measured in kilometers globally, while some regions prefer miles for training and shorter races.
FAQ.Q3: How do I convert my training paces between units?
FAQ.A3: When converting training plans between units, remember that pace also changes. A 6:00/mile pace equals approximately 3:44/km pace. Use our pace converter for accurate pace conversions, and our pace calculator to determine optimal training paces in your preferred unit.
FAQ.Q4: What are the standard race distances in both units?
FAQ.A4: Common race distances: 5K = 3.11 miles, 10K = 6.21 miles, Half Marathon = 21.1K = 13.11 miles, Marathon = 42.2K = 26.22 miles. Many races also use mile markers (1 mile = 1.61K). Use our finish time predictor to estimate your performance across different race distances.
FAQ.Q5: Should I train in kilometers or miles?
FAQ.A5: Train in the unit system you're most comfortable with or that matches your target races. If racing internationally, consider training in kilometers. If racing locally in mile-based regions, miles might be more intuitive. The key is consistency in your training log and understanding both systems for race planning.
FAQ.Q6: How does distance unit choice affect my training?
FAQ.A6: The unit choice doesn't affect your actual fitness or performance, but it can impact your mental approach and pacing strategy. Some runners find kilometer splits more motivating (smaller, more frequent milestones), while others prefer the traditional mile markers. Choose what helps you stay motivated and track progress effectively. Monitor your energy expenditure regardless of the distance unit you prefer.

PACE_SPEED_UNIT_CONVERTER.TITLE: Pace to Speed Converter
PACE_SPEED_UNIT_CONVERTER.DESCRIPTION: Convert between running pace (min/mile, min/km) and speed (mph, km/h) instantly. Perfect for treadmill training, comparing workout intensities, and understanding race paces.

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: What's the difference between pace and speed?
FAQ.A1: Pace is time per distance (e.g., 6:00 per mile or 3:44 per km), while speed is distance per time (e.g., 10 mph or 16 km/h). Runners typically prefer pace because it's easier to maintain consistent effort and plan race strategies. Use our pace calculator to determine optimal training paces.
FAQ.Q2: When should I use pace vs speed for training?
FAQ.A2: Use pace for most running training as it directly relates to effort level and race planning. Speed is more useful for treadmill settings, comparing with cycling/driving speeds, or scientific analysis. Most running watches and apps display pace because it's more intuitive for pacing strategies during races and workouts.
FAQ.Q3: How do I convert between different pace units?
FAQ.A3: This tool automatically converts between minutes per mile and minutes per kilometer. For manual conversion: multiply min/mile by 0.621 to get min/km, or multiply min/km by 1.609 to get min/mile. Understanding both units helps when following international training plans or racing abroad.
FAQ.Q4: What pace should I target for different types of runs?
FAQ.A4: Easy runs: 1-2 minutes per mile slower than race pace. Tempo runs: 15-30 seconds per mile slower than 10K pace. Interval training: 5K pace or faster. Long runs: 30-90 seconds per mile slower than marathon pace. Use our race time predictor to establish your baseline paces.
FAQ.Q5: How does terrain affect my pace?
FAQ.A5: Hills significantly slow pace - expect 15-30 seconds per mile slower on moderate hills, more on steep terrain. Trail running is typically 30-60 seconds per mile slower than road pace due to uneven surfaces and obstacles. Adjust your target pace accordingly and focus on effort level rather than exact pace on challenging terrain.
FAQ.Q6: Should I focus on improving pace or maintaining it longer?
FAQ.A6: For distance runners, maintaining pace longer (endurance) is usually more important than pure speed. Build your aerobic base first, then add speed work. For 5K and shorter, speed development becomes more important. Monitor your training load with our calories burned calculator to balance intensity and volume.

WEIGHT_UNIT_CONVERTER.TITLE: Weight Converter - Kilograms to Pounds Calculator
WEIGHT_UNIT_CONVERTER.DESCRIPTION: Convert body weight between kilograms and pounds for fitness tracking and international training programs.
WEIGHT_UNIT_CONVERTER.RESULT_SUBTITLE: Equivalent weights in kilograms and pounds

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: What's the exact conversion between kilograms and pounds?
FAQ.A1: 1 kilogram equals 2.20462 pounds, and 1 pound equals 0.453592 kilograms. This tool uses precise conversion factors to ensure accuracy for all your fitness and health tracking needs. Understanding both units helps when following international training programs or using equipment with different measurement systems.
FAQ.Q2: Why do some countries use kilograms while others use pounds?
FAQ.A2: Most countries worldwide use the metric system (kilograms), while the United States and a few others primarily use the imperial system (pounds) for body weight. In fitness and running, this means training programs, equipment, and health guidelines may be expressed in different units depending on their origin.
FAQ.Q3: How does my weight affect my running performance?
FAQ.A3: Body weight significantly impacts running performance, especially in distance events. Generally, carrying less excess weight improves running economy and speed. However, optimal weight varies by individual and should support overall health and performance. Use our BMI calculator to assess if your weight is in a healthy range for your height.
FAQ.Q4: Should I track my weight in kilograms or pounds?
FAQ.A4: Use the unit system you're most comfortable with or that matches your local healthcare and fitness environment. Many runners prefer kilograms because smaller incremental changes (0.1 kg vs 0.2 lbs) can provide more precise tracking. The key is consistency in your tracking method and understanding both systems when needed.
FAQ.Q5: How does weight affect calorie burn during running?
FAQ.A5: Heavier runners burn more calories per mile because they're moving more mass against gravity. The relationship is roughly linear - a 10% increase in weight typically results in about 10% more calories burned at the same pace and distance. Use our calories burned calculator to estimate your energy expenditure based on your current weight.
FAQ.Q6: What's a healthy weight range for runners?
FAQ.A6: Healthy weight for runners varies greatly by individual, body composition, and running goals. Elite distance runners often have lower BMIs, but recreational runners should prioritize overall health over performance weight. Focus on maintaining a weight that supports your energy levels, recovery, and long-term health. Consider consulting with healthcare professionals and use our VO₂ max calculator to assess your fitness level regardless of weight.

BMI_CALCULATOR.TITLE: BMI Calculator & Body Composition Analysis
BMI_CALCULATOR.DESCRIPTION: Comprehensive body composition calculator for runners and athletes. Calculate BMI, body fat percentage, ideal weight, and basal metabolic rate (BMR). Uses advanced formulas including New BMI for accurate results. Free health assessment tool. Includes:
BMI_CALCULATOR.DESCRIPTION_2:
• Standard BMI
  • New BMI - height-adjusted BMI
  • IBW - ideal body weight
  • Body Fat % - estimated using Deurenberg formula
  • BMR - calories burned at rest
BMI_CALCULATOR.RESULT_SUBTITLE: Based on your height, weight, age and sex

CATEGORY.IBW_BAD: Your weight is far from ideal

HOW_TO_USE.TITLE: How to Use the BMI Calculator
HOW_TO_USE.STEP1: 1. Enter your basic information: Input your age, sex, height, and weight using your preferred units. The calculator automatically adjusts for different measurement systems.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP2: 2. Review all metrics: Get comprehensive results including BMI, New BMI, body fat percentage, ideal body weight, and basal metabolic rate (BMR).
HOW_TO_USE.STEP3: 3. Understand your results: Each metric provides different insights into your health and fitness. Compare your values with the healthy ranges provided.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP4: 4. Use for health planning: Apply these metrics to set realistic fitness goals, plan nutrition, and track progress over time.

BMI_RANGES.TITLE: BMI Categories
BMI_RANGES.UNDERWEIGHT: Underweight: Below 18.5 - May indicate insufficient body weight
BMI_RANGES.NORMAL: Normal weight: 18.5-24.9 - Healthy weight range for most people
BMI_RANGES.OVERWEIGHT: Overweight: 25-29.9 - Above normal weight, consider lifestyle changes
BMI_RANGES.OBESE: Obese: 30+ - Significantly above healthy weight, consult healthcare provider

BODY_FAT.TITLE: Body Fat Percentage Ranges
BODY_FAT.ATHLETE_NOTE: Note: Runners typically maintain lower body fat percentages for optimal performance

HEALTH_TIPS.TITLE: Health and Fitness Recommendations
HEALTH_TIPS.INTRO: Use these evidence-based strategies to optimize your body composition and overall health:

WEIGHT_MANAGEMENT.TITLE: Healthy Weight Management
WEIGHT_MANAGEMENT.TIP1: Create moderate calorie deficits through balanced diet and exercise
WEIGHT_MANAGEMENT.TIP2: Focus on sustainable lifestyle changes rather than quick fixes
WEIGHT_MANAGEMENT.TIP3: Monitor progress through multiple metrics, not just weight

RUNNERS.TITLE: Specific Tips for Runners
RUNNERS.TIP1: Maintain adequate body fat for hormone production and injury prevention
RUNNERS.TIP2: Prioritize muscle mass preservation during weight loss phases
RUNNERS.TIP3: Use BMR to calculate daily calorie needs including training demands

WEIGHT_CONVERTER.DESC: Convert between different weight measurement systems

PACE_CALC.TITLE: Pace Calculator
PACE_CALC.DESC: Calculate optimal training paces for your fitness level

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: What is a healthy BMI for runners?
FAQ.A1: For runners, a BMI between 18.5-24.9 is considered healthy. However, many elite distance runners have BMIs on the lower end (18.5-22) due to their lean muscle mass and low body fat. The "New BMI" calculation in our tool provides a more accurate assessment for taller athletes.
FAQ.Q2: What's the difference between BMI and New BMI?
FAQ.A2: Traditional BMI can be inaccurate for very tall or short people. The "New BMI" (also called BMI Prime) uses a height exponent of 2.5 instead of 2, providing more accurate results for athletes and people outside average height ranges. This is especially useful for runners who tend to be taller.
FAQ.Q3: How do I calculate my BMR (Basal Metabolic Rate)?
FAQ.A3: BMR is the number of calories your body burns at rest. Our calculator uses the Mifflin-St Jeor equation, which is considered the most accurate. For runners, knowing your BMR helps determine daily calorie needs for training and recovery. Multiply your BMR by 1.6-1.9 depending on your training intensity. Use our Calories Burned Calculator to estimate calories burned during runs.
FAQ.Q4: What is Ideal Body Weight (IBW) and why does it matter?
FAQ.A4: IBW is your optimal weight based on height and gender using the Devine formula. For runners, being close to your IBW can improve performance by optimizing your power-to-weight ratio. However, muscle mass and body composition are more important than hitting an exact number.
FAQ.Q5: How accurate is body fat percentage calculation?
FAQ.A5: Our body fat calculator uses the Deurenberg formula, which provides a reasonable estimate based on BMI, age, and gender. For runners, healthy body fat ranges are typically 6-13% for men and 14-20% for women. For more precise measurements, consider DEXA scans or hydrostatic weighing.
FAQ.Q6: Should runners focus on BMI or body composition?
FAQ.A6: While BMI is a useful screening tool, runners should focus more on body composition (muscle vs. fat ratio). A runner with high muscle mass might have a higher BMI but excellent health. Use BMI alongside body fat percentage and performance metrics like VO2 Max for a complete picture.

TRAINING_PACES_CALCULATOR.TITLE: My Training Paces
TRAINING_PACES_CALCULATOR.DESCRIPTION: Calculate personalized training paces based on your recent run. Get recovery, base, conversational, and tempo paces for optimal training zones and improved performance.

INPUT.TITLE: Enter Your Recent Race
INPUT.DESCRIPTION: Input the distance and time from a recent race or maximum effort run to calculate your personalized training paces.

SUMMARY.TITLE: Your Training Paces
SUMMARY.SUBTITLE: Personalized pace zones for optimal training
SUMMARY.DESCRIPTION: Based on your recent run performance

AEROBIC_LOW.TITLE: Aerobic Low Intensity (Zone 1-2)
AEROBIC_LOW.DESC: Foundation training paces for building aerobic base, promoting recovery, and developing endurance. Easy runs should feel effortless, while base/long runs should be comfortable and conversational.

HIGH_AEROBIC.TITLE: High Intensity Aerobic (Zone 3-4)
HIGH_AEROBIC.DESC: Challenging but sustainable paces that improve lactate threshold, VO₂ max, and race-specific fitness. These require focused effort but remain aerobic.

ANAEROBIC.TITLE: Anaerobic (Zone 5)
ANAEROBIC.DESC: High-intensity paces that develop speed, power, and anaerobic capacity. These are used for short intervals with adequate recovery between efforts.

CURRENT.TITLE: Current Pace
CURRENT.DESC: Your pace from the recent run

EASY_RUN.TITLE: Easy/Recovery Run
EASY_RUN.DESC: Very slow recovery pace. Should feel effortless and restorative. True conversational pace.

BASE_RUN.TITLE: Base Run
BASE_RUN.DESC: Comfortable aerobic pace for building endurance foundation. Most of your weekly mileage.

LONG_RUN.TITLE: Long Run
LONG_RUN.DESC: Same pace as base runs but for extended duration. Focus on time and endurance, not speed.

TEMPO_RUN.TITLE: Tempo Run
TEMPO_RUN.DESC: Comfortably hard pace you could sustain for 15-20 minutes. Improves lactate threshold.

THRESHOLD_RUN.TITLE: Threshold Run
THRESHOLD_RUN.DESC: The fastest pace you can sustain aerobically. Critical for improving race performance.

VO2MAX_RUN.TITLE: VO₂ Max Run
VO2MAX_RUN.DESC: Hard effort pace for 3-8 minute intervals. Develops maximum oxygen uptake and running economy.

ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.TITLE: Anaerobic Intervals
ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.DESC: Very fast pace for short intervals (30 seconds to 2 minutes). Develops speed and anaerobic power.

SPRINTS.TITLE: Sprints
SPRINTS.DESC: Maximum effort pace for very short bursts (10-30 seconds). Develops neuromuscular power and speed.

HOW_TO_USE.TITLE: How to Use Your Training Paces
HOW_TO_USE.STEP1: 1. Enter race effort data: Input distance and time from a recent race or maximum effort run that represents your current fitness level - ideally a time trial or race where you gave 100% effort.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP2: 2. Review your pace zones: The calculator provides six different training paces based on proven training zone percentages used by elite coaches worldwide.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP3: 3. Apply to your training: Use these paces for different types of workouts throughout your training week to optimize performance and prevent overtraining.
HOW_TO_USE.STEP4: 4. Monitor and adjust: Update your paces every 4-6 weeks as your fitness improves, or after completing a race or time trial.

EASY_RUN.TITLE: Easy/Recovery Run (55-70% slower than race pace)
EASY_RUN.PURPOSE: Purpose: Active recovery, stress relief, promoting adaptation
EASY_RUN.EFFORT: Effort: Very easy, should feel effortless and restorative
EASY_RUN.BENEFITS: Benefits: Promotes recovery, improves fat burning, builds aerobic base

BASE_RUN.TITLE: Base Run (25-35% slower than race pace)
BASE_RUN.PURPOSE: Purpose: Build aerobic capacity and endurance foundation
BASE_RUN.BENEFITS: Benefits: Develops aerobic enzymes and cardiovascular efficiency

LONG_RUN.TITLE: Long Run (25-35% slower than race pace)
LONG_RUN.PURPOSE: Purpose: Weekly long runs, marathon preparation, mental toughness
LONG_RUN.EFFORT: Effort: Same as base pace but for extended time/distance
LONG_RUN.FREQUENCY: Frequency: Once per week, gradually increasing distance
LONG_RUN.BENEFITS: Benefits: Improves glycogen storage, fat utilization, and endurance

TEMPO_RUN.TITLE: Tempo Run (15% slower than race pace)
TEMPO_RUN.PURPOSE: Purpose: Improve lactate threshold and race-specific fitness
TEMPO_RUN.BENEFITS: Benefits: Increases lactate clearance and running economy

THRESHOLD_RUN.TITLE: Threshold Run (8% slower than race pace)
THRESHOLD_RUN.PURPOSE: Purpose: Develop lactate threshold and anaerobic threshold
THRESHOLD_RUN.EFFORT: Effort: Hard but controlled, maximum steady-state effort
THRESHOLD_RUN.BENEFITS: Benefits: Improves ability to buffer and clear lactate

VO2MAX_RUN.TITLE: VO₂ Max Run (2% slower than race pace)
VO2MAX_RUN.PURPOSE: Purpose: Develop maximum oxygen uptake and running economy
VO2MAX_RUN.EFFORT: Effort: Hard effort, close to race pace intensity
VO2MAX_RUN.BENEFITS: Benefits: Increases VO₂ max, stroke volume, and oxygen delivery

ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.TITLE: Anaerobic Intervals (5% faster than race pace)
ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.PURPOSE: Purpose: Develop anaerobic power and speed endurance
ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.EFFORT: Effort: Very hard, faster than race pace for short bursts
ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.FREQUENCY: Frequency: 1 time per week, 30 seconds to 2 minutes
ANAEROBIC_INTERVALS.BENEFITS: Benefits: Improves anaerobic capacity and lactate tolerance

SPRINTS.TITLE: Sprints (10% faster than race pace)
SPRINTS.PURPOSE: Purpose: Develop neuromuscular power and maximum speed
SPRINTS.EFFORT: Effort: Maximum effort, significantly faster than race pace
SPRINTS.BENEFITS: Benefits: Improves running form, stride rate, and power

PACE_CALC.TITLE: Pace Calculator
PACE_CALC.DESC: Calculate pace, time, and distance for race planning

VO2MAX.TITLE: VO₂ Max Calculator
VO2MAX.DESC: Assess your aerobic fitness level from race performance

FINISH_TIME.TITLE: Race Time Predictor
FINISH_TIME.DESC: Predict finish times for different race distances

CALORIES.TITLE: Calories Burned Calculator
CALORIES.DESC: Track energy expenditure during training runs

FAQ.TITLE: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.Q1: How often should I update my training paces?
FAQ.A1: Update your training paces every 4-6 weeks as your fitness improves, or after completing a race or time trial. If you notice the paces feeling too easy or too hard consistently, it's time for an update.
FAQ.Q2: What type of run should I use to calculate my paces?
FAQ.A2: Use a recent race or maximum effort run where you gave 100% effort. This could be a 5K race, 10K race, time trial, or any distance where you pushed yourself to your limit. Avoid using casual training runs as they won't provide accurate training pace calculations.
FAQ.Q3: Why do I need to use a race effort instead of a regular training run?
FAQ.A3: Training paces are calculated as percentages of your maximum effort. If you input a casual training run, all your calculated paces will be too slow. Race efforts or time trials represent your true fitness level and provide the correct baseline for determining appropriate training intensities.
FAQ.Q4: What's the difference between tempo and threshold runs?
FAQ.A4: Tempo runs are moderately hard (15% slower than race pace) and sustainable for 15-20 minutes, while threshold runs are harder (8% slower than race pace) and represent your maximum steady-state effort. Both improve lactate processing but at different intensities.
FAQ.Q5: How often should I do high-intensity and anaerobic workouts?
FAQ.A5: Limit high-intensity aerobic work (tempo, threshold, VO₂ max) to 2-3 sessions per week, and anaerobic work (intervals, sprints) to 1-2 sessions per week. Always allow adequate recovery between hard sessions to prevent overtraining.
FAQ.Q6: Why are my easy run paces so much slower than my race pace?
FAQ.A6: Easy/recovery paces are intentionally much slower (55-70% slower than race pace) to promote true recovery and stress relief. These runs should feel effortless and restorative. Many runners make the mistake of running too fast on easy days, which prevents proper recovery and limits training adaptations.
FAQ.Q7: How do I know if I'm running at the right effort level?
FAQ.A7: Use the 'talk test' - for easy paces you should be able to hold a conversation, for tempo pace you should be able to speak in short sentences, and for VO₂ max/anaerobic efforts speaking becomes very difficult. Heart rate monitors can also help validate effort levels.
FAQ.Q8: Can I use these paces for race planning?
FAQ.A8: Yes! Your threshold pace approximates your 10K-15K race pace, tempo pace is close to half-marathon pace, and your long run pace helps establish marathon pacing strategy. Use our Race Time Predictor for more specific race pace guidance.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.content: Welcome to Runner Toolkit. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, disclose, and safeguard your information when you use our running calculator and fitness tools application.
introduction.commitment: We are committed to protecting your privacy and ensuring you understand how your information is handled.

analytics.title: Analytics Data (Firebase Analytics)
analytics.content: We use Firebase Analytics to understand how users interact with our application. This service automatically collects:

items.usage_data: App usage patterns and feature interactions

local_storage.title: Local Storage Data
local_storage.content: We store certain information locally on your device to enhance your experience:

adsense.title: Google AdSense and Advertising
adsense.content: We use Google AdSense to display advertisements. Google AdSense uses cookies and similar technologies to serve ads based on your interests.

cookies.title: Advertising Cookies
cookies.content: Google AdSense may place and read cookies on your browser, or use web beacons to collect information in the course of ads being served.

personalization.title: Ad Personalization
personalization.content: Ads may be personalized based on your interests. You can control ad personalization through Google's Ad Settings.

firebase.title: Firebase Analytics and User Tracking
firebase.content: We use Firebase Analytics to collect information about how you use our app. This helps us improve our services and understand user behavior.
firebase.opt_out: You can opt out of Google Analytics tracking by installing the Google Analytics Opt-out Browser Add-on.

items.improve_service: Improve and optimize our application and services
items.understand_usage: Understand how users interact with our features
items.personalize_ads: Provide relevant advertisements through Google AdSense
items.technical_issues: Identify and fix technical issues and bugs
items.security: Maintain the security and integrity of our services

legal_basis.title: Legal Basis for Processing (GDPR)
legal_basis.content: Under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), we process your personal data based on the following legal grounds:

legitimate_interest.name: Legitimate Interest
legitimate_interest.description: Analytics and app improvement (Firebase Analytics) - we have a legitimate business interest in understanding how our app is used

consent.name: Consent
consent.description: Advertising cookies and personalized ads (Google AdSense) - you can withdraw consent at any time through browser settings

contract.name: Contract Performance
contract.description: Essential app functionality and user preferences - necessary to provide the service you requested

data_sharing.title: Information Sharing and Disclosure
data_sharing.content: We do not sell, trade, or otherwise transfer your personal information to third parties except as described below:

items.google_analytics: Google Analytics and Firebase for analytics purposes
items.legal_requirements: When required by law or to protect our rights

data_controller.title: Data Controller Information
data_controller.content: For the purposes of data protection law, the data controller of your personal information is:
data_controller.name: Data Controller

international_transfers.title: International Data Transfers
international_transfers.content: Your personal data may be transferred to and processed in countries outside your country of residence, including the United States, where Google's servers are located.

items.adequacy_decisions: Transfers to countries with European Commission adequacy decisions
items.privacy_framework: EU-US Data Privacy Framework for transfers to the United States
items.google_compliance: Google's compliance with international data protection standards and contractual safeguards

your_rights.title: Your Privacy Rights
your_rights.content: Under GDPR and other privacy laws, you have the following rights:

items.access: Right to access your personal data
items.rectification: Right to correct inaccurate personal data
items.erasure: Right to request deletion of your personal data
items.objection: Right to object to processing of your personal data

cookies.title: Cookies and Tracking Technologies
cookies.content: We use cookies and similar tracking technologies to enhance your experience and provide our services.

essential.name: Essential Cookies
essential.description: Required for basic app functionality and user preferences

analytics.name: Analytics Cookies
analytics.description: Help us understand how you use our app (Firebase Analytics)

advertising.name: Advertising Cookies
advertising.description: Used to serve relevant ads (Google AdSense)

data_retention.title: Data Retention
data_retention.content: We retain your information for different periods depending on the type of data and its purpose:

items.analytics: Analytics data (Firebase): Automatically deleted after 26 months (Google's default retention period)
items.local_storage: Local storage data: Retained until you clear your browser data, uninstall the app, or manually delete it
items.advertising: Advertising cookies: Typically expire after 30 days to 2 years depending on the specific cookie

security.title: Data Security
security.content: We implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to protect your personal information against unauthorized access, alteration, disclosure, or destruction. However, no method of transmission over the internet is 100% secure.

children.title: Children's Privacy
children.content: Our service is not intended for children under 13 years of age. We do not knowingly collect personal information from children under 13. If you are a parent or guardian and believe your child has provided us with personal information, please contact us.

changes.title: Changes to This Privacy Policy
changes.content: We may update this Privacy Policy from time to time. We will notify you of any changes by posting the new Privacy Policy on this page and updating the 'Last Updated' date. You are advised to review this Privacy Policy periodically for any changes.

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.content: If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy or our privacy practices, please contact us:

cookie_consent.title: We Use Cookies
cookie_consent.description: We use cookies to enhance your experience, analyze site usage, and provide personalized advertisements. You can customize your preferences or accept all cookies.
cookie_consent.description_returning: Thank you for using Runner Toolkit! We're asking again about cookies to ensure you have the best experience. Your support helps us keep this app free and continuously improve our tools for runners worldwide.
cookie_consent.privacy_policy_link: Learn more in our Privacy Policy

essential.title: Essential Cookies
essential.description: Required for basic website functionality, user preferences, and security. Cannot be disabled.

analytics.title: Analytics Cookies
analytics.description: Help us understand how you use our app through Firebase Analytics. Used to improve performance and user experience.

advertising.title: Advertising Cookies
advertising.description: Used by Google AdSense to show relevant advertisements and measure ad effectiveness. May track you across websites.

help_us.title: Help us keep Runner Toolkit free!
help_us.description: This app is completely free thanks to ads and analytics. Your acceptance helps us improve features and develop new tools for runners worldwide.

no_consent.title: Ads Disabled
no_consent.description: You haven't consented to advertising cookies. Please enable them to help keep Runner Toolkit free and support our development.

ad_blocker.title: Ad Blocker Detected
ad_blocker.description: Help us keep Runner Toolkit free by allowing ads. Your support enables us to maintain and improve these tools for the running community.
ad_blocker.request: Please disable your ad blocker on our site.
